thread.title: From healthcare to terrorism - what North East voters are Googling this election

author: Jonathan Walker
title: From healthcare to terrorism - what North East voters are Googling this election
text:
Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The NHS is the main issue for the North East going into the June 8 general election, according to data provided by Google . 
Healthcare was the most searched political issue in 13 constituencies in the region. 
They included Hexham in Northumberland , Newcastle Central, Wansbeck, Tynemouth, North West Durham, Easington and others. 
The EU and Brexit are the issues Conservative leader Theresa May is focusing on in this election. 
But only voters in the constituencies of Houghton and Sunderland South, Sedgefield and Bishop Auckland searched for these issues more than anything else. 
Pensions were the top concern of voters in Newcastle North and North Tyneside, based on their searches. Liberal Democrats leader Tim Farron, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, Green Party co-leader Caroline Lucas, Plaid Cymru leader Leanne Wood, Home Secretary Amber Rudd, Ukip leader Paul Nuttall and SNP deputy leader Angus Robertson take part in the BBC Election Debate hosted by BBC news presenter Mishal Husain, as it is broadcast live from Senate House on May 31, 2017 (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
And voters in Blyth Valley, Northumberland, searched for information about terrorism more than any other subject. 
Perhaps surprisingly, voters in Blaydon and North Durham searched for religion more than anything other issue connected to politics. 
Google tracked search queries across the UK from October 2016 to April 2017 and gave the results to the Chronicle. 
The NHS was the most searched-for topic in almost two-thirds of constituencies across the country, some 402 out of 650. 
The EU and Brexit came out on top in 86 seats, while pensions were the most interesting to voters in 70 seats. 
Labour have promised that the NHS will get £6billion a year extra raised from new taxes on the nation’s highest earners. A voter placing a ballot paper in the ballot box (Photo: Rui Vieira/PA Wire) 
The Conservatives have pledged that NHS spending ‘will rise £8bn in real terms’ by 2022, the party’s manifesto states. To help raise funds, the fees charged to migrants for using the NHS would be tripled. 
The Tories have also stated that they would introduce the first new mental health Bill for 30 years. Top issues:
